title: Ravi Shastri - Cricketer, Commentator And Now The Team India Coach
text:
Ravi Shastri is a former Indian cricketer, commentator, and the current coach of the India national cricket team. He played for India between 1981 and 1992. His moment of glory came in 1983 when he was part of the Indian team that won the World Cup in England.

The individual highlight of his career was when he was elected Champion of Champions in the World Championship of Cricket in Australia in 1985. He was appointed the coach of Indian cricket team in 2017, and continuous in that capacity currently.

Who is Ravi Shastri?

PTI

Born in Mumbai, he took serious interest in the game of cricket at a very early age. Although, he started out as a left-arm orthodox bowler, but later transformed into a batting all-rounder. He later made a name for himself as a commentator before getting down to the coaching duties. A cricketer, commentator, and now a coach - Ravi Shastri has done it all.

Early Life

Part of the famous squad that won the World Cup in 1983, Ravi Shastri was born on 27 May, 1962, in Mumbai, Maharashtra.

Ravi Shastri found interest in cricket at a very small age. Playing for Don Bosco (Matunga), Shastri reached the final of the 1976 inter-school Giles Shield, finally losing to St Mary's. In the next year, Ravi Shastri who was captaining Don Bosco romped to a inter-school Giles Shield win.

It was also the first time that Don Bosco had won the tournament in school's history. While Don Bosco was not traditionally a major force in schools cricket, the R.A. Podar College, where Shastri later studied commerce, produced many good cricketers.

Early Career

Getty Images

When Shastri was in last year of his junior college, he was picked to represent Bombay in the Ranji Trophy. At 17 years and 292 days, he was then the youngest cricketer to play for Bombay. His only notable achievement in his first two Ranji seasons were bowling figures of 6-61, which he took against Delhi in the 1979–80 Ranji final that Bombay lost.

The following season while playing against Uttar Pradesh, he got his maiden call up to the Indian team was called up to the squad touring New Zealand to stand in for the injured left arm spinner Dilip Doshi. While making his debut against New Zealand, Shastri went wicket less in the first innings, but went on to get three wickets in four ball in the second innings.

The showing in the debut Test gave him confidence and belief, and he went on to get seven in the 3rd Test, which won him the man of the match award. He ended the series with 15 scalps, most for a bowler in the series for either side.

1983 World Cup and Retirement

Ravi Shastri soon began to establish himself in the Indian team. He used to bat lower down the order, but his sensible contribution were rewarded as he was promoted up the order. His batting improved immensely as began to be seen as a batting all-rounder. In 1983, he was part of the famous squad that lifted the World Cup aloft at Lord's. An achievement considered monumental as India broke the West Indies dominance and scripted a historic chapter in the cricket history.

In 1984, Ravi Shastri started making more impact with both bat and ball. It was with the bat that he was showing great improvement and scoring runs. Around this time, Shastri also began to open the innings regularly in one day games. He scored 102 against Australia in October – India's second hundred in ODIs – and made the same score against England at Cuttack in December. He continued his batting heroics against England as his 235 run stand with Syed Kirmani led India to victory.

He continued to score big runs for India in the Test, but was not much successful in the ODIs. After suffering a knee injury, Shastri was out of action for eight months, but he never really found his way back. Having played his last game against South Africa in December, 1992, he called time on his career.

Post Retirement and Coaching

AFP

After his retirement from the game, Ravi Shastri started commentating. He made his debut as a TV commentator with the World Masters Tournament in Mumbai in March 1995. After curving out a a successful commentary stint, and making a name for being one of the best in field.

He made quite an impact with his commentary, going on to become one of the revered and famous commentators. His commentary during the final moments of India's World Cup win still gives goosebumps to this day.

After a very eminent stint in the world of commentary, he moved back to the every day hassle of coaching. He was appointed as the coach of Indian cricket team. As the World cup 2019 was in progress, the BCCI announced an extension of Shastri's contract by 45 days after the tournament.

In August 2019, he was re-appointed as the head coach of the senior men's Indian team, with his new contract extending up to the 2021 ICC T20 World Cup in India. He continues to serve in that capacity currently.
